description.narrative:
ILRIG has conducted research in areas of different and new forms of organising, amendments to the labour law, changes in capitalism , restructuring the working class and the implication for precarious workers special working women, current wave of automation and mechanisations, feminist perspective on financialisation, social grants and the indebtness of working class women, land occupation and service delivery protests in South Africa, political self-sustaining struggles, impact of neoliberalism on education.

ILRIG continued with the focus from last year with targeted organisations assisting them to understand the root causes of the problems they face; assisting with experimenting with new forms of organising; promoting the idea of the need to unify struggles, and promoting progressive revolutionary politics, including feminism within the formations.

Through the medium of Forum Theatre ILRIG undertook Building Women´s Activism sessions in Gauteng focusing on how gender based violence is linked to patriarchy and capitalism. A joint Building Women´s Activism workshops with women farm workers from 2 different trade unions aimed to support each other not only to challenge patriarchy in the workplace and communities but also in their unions.

ILRIG also supported GIWUSA (union) in terms of popular education and with assistance in self-organising. With the assistance from ILRIG Phillipi High School a brick school is being built, a solid layer of cadres have emerged, in particular women and through ILRIG´s assistance on popular education the focus on the content of the education will shift and change.

ILRIG held 2 Provincial Platforms with the objective to support coordinated struggles for land, housing and services. Two editions of the Workers World News, nine articles for external publication were produced.in 9 interviews in different media platforms ILRIG commented on contemporary social, economic and political developments.

ILRIG is a South African research institute . ILRIG works within three focus areas Community Struggles and New Forms; Workers Struggles and New Forms; and Student/Youth Struggles and New Forms.The overall objective is to support the building of a strong, independent, critically thinking, feminist, and united movement that is based on new forms of organising and that seeks an alternative to capitalism. This is done by building unity and capacity to mount successful campaigns against neoliberal public policies which perpetuate poverty in South Africa and the broader region and strengthen and build resilient formations, based on new forms of organising, of the working class, strengthen a layer of feminist activists in these formations, new forms of organising, build on activists understanding of the conditions and manifestations of neoliberalism, to provide organising spaces and to assist formations reflect on and sharpen their strategy and tactics in a complex environment, to arm activists with tools of analysis.
